content.text: Standing in a crawling position touching the floor at 6 points: 2 palms open wide (shoulder wide), 2 knees (hips wide) and both the front of the legs and feet and rocking. While crawling on all 6 points, the body pulling himself to one side where he puts all his weight and lifts his other side and then switch to the other side and vice versa.

Making the shoulder belt muscles strong and ready for a good fine motor skills that are coming when the baby starts to sit by himself and of course for school. Upper body and lower body are working together and it is very important for the milestones to come. Here too the hand and foot coordination is happening and if not passing the army crawl stage this is the time for the body to work on it and increase the connection of the nerve system in the brain.
At this stage the level of independence increases due to the ability to explore more of their surroundings and the level of curiosity rises.

If you are seeing that your baby has a hard time achieving the specific milestones described in the description or are at the age of 10 months and canâ€™t do those things you should consult with your pediatrician or an Infant development guide in order to learn how to help your baby to achieve these important abilities that are the foundation of their physical, sensory and emotional needs:

ul: The distance between the palms is not wider than their shoulders
The distance between the knees is not wider than their pelvis
Both knees are touching the surface
